title: 108_hr4841
content: The "Tax Simplification for Americans Act of 2004" changes the filing status of head of household to single head of household. The "Tax Simplification for Americans Act of 2004" amends various provisions in the Internal Revenue Code by replacing "head of a household" with "single head of household." This includes changes to sections 1, 2, 25B, 151, and 6012. Additionally, other conforming amendments are made to section 63 and the heading for subsection (b) of section 1. The heading for section 2(b) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to read as "Definition of Single Head of Household." The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2004. SEC. 3. EXPANDED AVAILABILITY OF 1040EZ AND 1040A. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish a dollar threshold for using Forms 1040EZ and 1040A. An individual can use Form 1040EZ and Form 1040A for filing income tax returns as long as their taxable income does not exceed $100,000. This amount is subject to inflation adjustments after 2004. The taxable income limit for using Form 1040EZ and Form 1040A is $100,000, subject to inflation adjustments. Amounts in multiples of $10,000 will be rounded to the nearest multiple. A new item is added to the table of sections for chapter 77 of the Code. The taxable income limit for using Form 1040EZ and Form 1040A is $100,000, subject to inflation adjustments. A new item is added to the table of sections for chapter 77 of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003. The tax tables are adjusted to prevent tax increases due to inflation. The cost-of-living adjustment for certain tax brackets is changed. Amendments are made to the earned income credit section of the Internal Revenue Code. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including annuities, life insurance contracts, accident and health plans, and flexible spending arrangements. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changes to combat zone compensation for armed forces members, principal residence rules, and reduced uniformed services retirement pay. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changes related to mortgage revenue bonds, state legislators' travel expenses, and health insurance costs for self-employed individuals. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changes related to interest deductions, amounts received by surviving annuitants, and income taxes of members of the armed forces on death. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changes related to income taxes of members of the armed forces on death, tax on nonresident alien individuals, old-age, survivors, and disability insurance, and hospital insurance. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changes related to income taxes of members of the armed forces on death, tax on nonresident alien individuals, old-age, survivors, and disability insurance, and hospital insurance. The amendments also involve adjustments to self-employment income for ministers, members of religious orders, and Christian Science practitioners, as well as withholding tax on nonresident aliens and retirement benefits. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changes related to retirement benefits for judges, annuities for surviving spouses and dependent children, and adjustments to self-employment income for certain individuals. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code regarding retirement benefits, annuities, and self-employment income are being made. Subsections of section 7448 are amended to change interest rates to 3 percent per annum. The effective date of these amendments is the date of enactment of the Act, with provisions for transactions occurring before that date. The amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code regarding retirement benefits, annuities, and self-employment income include provisions for transactions occurring before the date of enactment. These changes do not affect the treatment of transactions, property, or items for determining tax liability for periods ending after the date of enactment. The House of Representatives passed the bill on July 21, 2004. Attest: JEFF TRANDAHL, Clerk.
